DOC.HEAD: Plant Operator Cited For Allowing Workers to Sleep on the Job
Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to ADD that award fees are incentive payments to the contractor. Picks up 3rd graf pvs `Westinghouse took ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department gave the new operator of the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant $3.9 million in award fees despite serious safety lapses such as workers found sleeping on duty, the agency said Tuesday. The award for Westinghouse Savannah River Co.'s first six months at the site near Aiken, S.C., amounted to 52.5 percent of the maximum possible award under terms of its contract, the department said in a letter to Westinghouse last Wednesday. The contract provides for incentive payments, or award fees, if the contractor meets criteria set by the department. Westinghouse took over for E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. in April amid concern that Du Pont had allowed safety standards to fall dangerously low. Du Pont had run the plant since it was built in the early 1950s. In the letter, P.W. Kaspar, manager of the department's Savannah River operations office, told Westinghouse Savannah River President James Moore that while the company had made some important improvements, its overall approach to instilling greater discipline in plant operations was too narrow and not yet effective. Kaspar said the department's Award Fee Board, which evaluated Westinghouse's performance from April 1 through Sept. 30, had assigned a rating of 82 points out of a possible 100. Kaspar personally knocked one point off the rating, resulting in an award total of $3.9 million out of a maximum possible $7.5 million. ``The reason for this reduction was my assessment that progress made to date on improving conduct of operations is inadequate and not sufficiently reflected in the (board's) evaluation,'' Kaspar wrote. ``While training programs appear to be sound, there is insufficient on-shift coaching, rigorous enforcement of details and followup of anomalies throughout the site,'' he added. Among the anomalies cited by Kaspar was employees found sleeping on the job. Kaspar's letter provided no details, but plant spokesman Dean Hoffman said Tuesday that two employees, in separate incidents, had been found asleep when they were supposed to have been monitoring the testing of cooling pipes at the L reactor, one of three reactors at Savannah River that make a gas needed for nuclear warheads. All three reactors have been shut down for more than a year for safety improvements. Hoffman said unspecified ``disciplinary action'' was taken against the employees several months ago, although they were not fired. Kaspar attributed the sleeping incidents to excessive overtime required by Westinghouse. Another problem noted by Kaspar was the intentional disablement of alarms by Westinghouse employees. Hoffman said two employees recently were fired for tampering with alarms in two areas of the plant, including the P reactor. The alarms were installed to detect excessive amounts of radiation. Hoffman called the sleeping and alarm tampering ``isolated incidents'' and said the company had made important strides toward reaching Energy Department standards for operating the plant. He added that the company would not be satisfied with its overall performance until it reached the department's highest standards. Hoffman noted that the department had given Westinghouse an ``excellent'' rating for establishing and operating an integrated design, engineering and construction organization. Ratings in other areas were either ``good'' or ``marginal.''
